item.title: Life as the measure
item.description: Don‚Äôt know much about ecology, don‚Äôt know much economics either but what I do know is what a wonderful world it would be, if we used life as the measure, rather than human derived financial value (AKA money).

item.title: Estimate
item.description: Estimate per 100m¬≤ Assume clearing grass land 1 tonne bark or wood chip mulch, ¬£35 per tonne Approx 400 plants (3-5 per m¬≤) Approx 250g White Mustard seed temp ground cover plant Ground preparation Sheet mulch Sheet mulch per 100m¬≤ (2m x 50m) ¬£40 Metal pegs x50 ¬£10 Job Time Mow 3 hr Lay sheet mulch 3 hr Leave 2-3 mth Lift sheet mulch 3 hr Lay bark 6 hr Plant ground cover 4 hr Sow temp cover 1 hr Total 20 hr Scraping Mini-digger 1 day hire ¬£100 Digger drive 1 day ¬£100 Diesel ¬£20 Only cost effective for half hectare site, ‚Öì of which scraped ie 1500 m¬≤.

item.title: Nurse tree
item.description: A nurse tree is a fast-growing tree or shrub planted a couple of metres away from a newly planted specimen tree, in the windward direction, normally grown in groups of 2 or 3.

item.title: Hedgerows
item.description: Productive, low-maintenance, village forest garden Combining a mixture of vegetables, established hedges and forest garden, this medium-sized, gently sloping and south-facing rear garden provides plentiful opportunity for produce and wildlife.

item.title: Wildflower
item.description: Some suggestions from Twitter about starting out in the world of UK native wild flowers.

item.description: I‚Äôm fascinated by Benjamin Vogt‚Äôs idea of using modular design for a native garden meadow.

item.title: Chop ‚Äòn‚Äô drop
item.description: Comfrey is a garden workhorse. As a mineral accumulator, it‚Äôs rich in potassium and is used to make a liquid compost.

item.title: Recommended
item.description: Books Creating a Forest Garden by Martin Crawford A New Garden Ethic by Benjamin Vogt, the morality of gardening with natives The Wild Garden, by Violet Stevenson, 1985 but pretty much the only book covering the use of UK native plants Around the world in 80 plants by Stephen Barstow, a global romp around edible plants The Garden of Equal Delights by Anni Kelsey, forest gardening from the gardener‚Äôs perspective, delightful and intriguing Suppliers Backyard Larder, Alison Tindale Incredible Veg, Mandy Barber Agroforestry Research Trust, Martin Crawford Cool Temperate, Phil Corbett Future Forests, for hedging Websites Plants For A Future brilliant database of useful plants, essential Database of Insects & their Food intoxifying amount of info about which plants are hosts for which insects orangepippin.

item.title: Top 10 perennial veg
item.description: Caucasian Spinach Day Lillies Welsh Onion Garden Sorrel Good King Henry Perennial Kale Perennial Leek Siberian Purslane Turkish Rocket Wild Garlic Big thank you to Alison Tindale at Backyard Larder for some great plants, profiles and photos, to Martin Crawford for writing Creating a Forest Garden, to Mandy Barber at Incredible Vegetables for the inspiration, and to Stephen Barstow for his unrelenting exploration of all things edimental.

item.title: My take on Planting in a Post-wild World
item.description: My entry into gardening was via the forest garden, so I find the emphasis on the ornamental in mainstream gardening quite perplexing, particularly after reading Benjamin Vogt‚Äôs A New Garden Ethic.

item.title: Hoverfly & wild pollinators research at Botanic Garden Wales
item.description: On a recent visit to Botanic Garden Wales, I met up with Abigail Lowe, a PhD student with the Garden‚Äôs Science Team who is continuing the critical research into which flowers pollinators prefer, focussing on the role of hoverflies.

item.title: The Japanese Forest Garden
item.description: At first glance, the idea of a Japanese Garden is at odds with a forest garden: clipped cloud hedges, carefully trained trees, layer upon layer of symbolism and meaning.

item.title: This is a local garden, for local species
item.description: Humans are strange creatures, capable of abstracting their minds unfathomable distances from their situation.

item.title: Creating a forest garden plan with a satellite background image
item.description: Using a CAD plan, it‚Äôs easy to move trees around to try out different ideas.

item.title: Green Room
item.description: ‚ÄúA green room in which to lose ourselves‚Äù The brief was to deliver a design that creates a sense of seclusion and enclosure with plants, whilst accomodating the existing garden structure and providing a range of habitats, features and food sources for wildlife.

item.description: Whilst designing a small wildlife forest garden for some clients in London, I was searching for information about the Teasel on the RHS plant finder.

item.description: Bruce‚Äôs talk on his well-established forest garden at Moylgrove Hall was very interesting, particularly because it is well-established.

item.description: You might have noticed a bit of heat being generated about Brexit recently.

item.description: Benjamin Vogt‚Äôs @BRVogt article Native Plants, Racism, & the Colonizing Nature of Garden Language is thought provoking stuff.

item.title: Pivot
item.description: I gambled on making a living from running forest garden tours and workshops, using the Airbnb network to get passing holiday trade.

item.title: Hawthorn all the way
item.description: I‚Äôm very lucky to be working on a large farm garden in Pembrokeshire.

item.title: Peat Free Nurseries
item.description: Using peat-based compost contributes to #ClimateBreakdown and wildlife habitat loss. Best thing you can do is use a peat-free compost (such as Sylvagrow, FertileFibre, Dalefoot etc) and buy your plants from a nursery that use peat-free compost.

item.title: PeatFree Climate Emergency
item.description: The peat extraction industry is a microcosm of the wider Climate Emergency.

item.title: Rhug
item.description: Low-maintenance holiday garden The original design was for curved herb and wild flower beds, providing shelter and screening for a hot tub, barbeque and green roof seating area.

item.title: Rhydgaled
item.description: Outline design for a keen forest gardener Having a keen forest gardener as a client is actually a boon for a forest garden designer!

item.title: My advice for a forest garden? Flowers and annual veg
item.description: I have the occasional taker for my forest garden tour and sharing what I know with others is something I really enjoy.

item.title: Let go control
item.description: The all-summer-rolling forest garden tours and workshops via Airbnb were always a bit of a gamble.

item.title: Biological recording workshop
item.description: West Wales Biodiversity Information Centre (WWBIC), made up of Pembrokeshire, Ceredigion & Carmarthen.

item.title: Wild Food Corridors
item.description: We need to protect and restore our wildlife whilst dramatically reducing our Greenhouse Gas emissions, which means sustainable food production on a global scale, something that can only happen with public awareness, understanding and support.

item.title: Clay lined pond
item.description: I‚Äôm creating yet another wildlife pond, this time in the Ornamental Forest Garden.

item.title: Designing wilderness well
item.description: @BotanicalMartin‚Äôs recent tweet resonated deeply with me: I think this will be a blueprint for many of our urban/suburban green spaces in the future - species-rich grassland (irregularly-cut) with scrub (irregularly coppiced), bramble, bare areas, open areas, well-trodden paths.

item.title: Forest garden ground cover preparation
item.description: In the original forest garden, I used vast amounts of woven plastic sheet mulch to clear the grass, before laying down bark mulch and planting perennial ground cover (a process I‚Äôve described previously).

item.description: At the end of my Introduction to Forest Gardening talk at Llechryd Gardening Club, the Club Secretary Lynda kindly offered some Tayberry bushes, suggesting that they would grow well on the south side of the dead hedge.

item.description: The Ornamental Forest Garden (OFG) plan is based on a satellite photo, so it should be more accurate than the Forest Garden One, which is based on a digital Ordnance Survey map.

item.description: The Climate Emergency and Mass Extinction is caused by living in an unsustainable way.

item.title: Why a forest garden is good for climate change
item.description: Climate change is caused by living in an unsustainable way. Forest gardens by definition are a sustainable and sustaining form of gardening.

item.description: We had our first forest garden tour and workshop last week, via Airbnb.

item.description: At the beginning of any forest garden project, I always recommend surveying and planning first, followed by propagating ground cover plants.

item.description: A couple of months ago, I went on a grafting workshop run by Steve Wilson and organised by The People‚Äôs Orchard.

item.description: The whole point of a forest garden is that you are working with nature to grow edible crops.

item.description: The whole point of a forest garden is that you are working with nature to grow edible crops.

item.title: Spacing
item.description: It‚Äôs important to leave enough space between trees in the canopy layer, so that there‚Äôs enough light coming through to the plants below.

item.title: Tree spacing in the forest garden
item.description: It‚Äôs important to leave enough space between trees in the canopy layer, so that there‚Äôs enough light coming through to the plants below.

item.title: Wildflower meadow genesis
item.description: A neighbour has very kindly lent us a brush cutter, so I‚Äôve been busy for the past couple of weeks clearing the bramble from the coppice area (pictured above) to plant more trees, and the 2 acre sloping pasture so that we can create a wildflower meadow.

item.title: Act right now on climate
item.description: I went on the local Strike4Climate demonstration with my two children on Friday, part of their education in our democratic ways.

item.title: Designing a small forest garden
item.description: I really think that your small garden can be a forest garden, because to be a forest garden is more abut the principles than the size.

item.description: Steve Wilson, the tutor at a recent People‚Äôs Orchard grafting workshop, discussed how his wildflower meadow encourages pollinators.

item.title: Our forest garden tours & workshops setup
item.description: I‚Äôve organised the forest garden tours and workshops for 2019. I decided to market them as Airbnb holiday Experiences because it is a vast amount of work to manage an online shop, calendar and publicity.

item.description: We‚Äôve planted the canopy layer in the Ornamental Forest Garden, a new, greenfield, 1 acre site.

item.description: We‚Äôve planted Amelanchier canadensis, Elaeagnus umbellata, Berberis darwinii and Viburnum opulus in the northern double-width windbreak hedge of the Ornamental Forest Garden.

item.description: Windbreak hedges are essential for protecting plants in the forest garden.

item.description: Things have started happening in the Ornamental Forest Garden‚Äîwe have the beginnings of a Northern Hedge, the plants from ScotPlants Direct are arriving tomorrow, and the digger cometh.

item.description: Some plants in the garden if left to their own devices will just take over, bramble (Rubus fruticosus) being an excellent example.

item.title: Benefits of a Forest Garden
item.description: Plentiful, reliable and low maintenance food crops Biodiversity, shelter and increased wildlife Low energy, low input gardening Improved soil health and vitality Captures carbon via trees and soil life Beautiful & functional

item.description: Looking forward to the spring, I‚Äôm running our first forest garden tours and workshops.

item.title: Your small garden can be a forest garden
item.description: One drawback with forest gardening is the name. Firstly, it emulates the edge of a woodland, not the deepest, darkest depths of a forest.

item.title: Inspirational women (some of them in horticulture)
item.description: I‚Äôm a latecomer to the gardening party and I sometimes feel like a gatecrasher, inadvertently swept in on the coat-tails of forest gardening (you know, the scruffy one with the wild look in its eye).

item.description: Our 2019 workshops and tours are now available to book on Airbnb:

item.description: We started creating a forest garden about 3 years ago. I always recommend people thoroughly read Creating a Forest Garden by Martin Crawford.

item.description: There‚Äôs a metric tonne of powdered lime in the Dutch Barn that needs to make way for the annual thinning of the 2 acre woodland.

item.title: Gardening with urgency and purpose
item.description: I am not a natural born gardener. I‚Äôve come to it late, initially provoked by the threat of climate change and tantalised by the prospect of a productive, low maintenance, wildlife friendly forest garden.

item.title: Now is the best time for hardwood cuttings
item.description: The best time for hardwood cuttings is from mid-autumn until late winter.

item.title: The surveying legwork of the Ornamental #ForestGarden
item.description: ‚ÄúNever mind surveying the forest garden plot, my plants are arriving this afternoon!

item.title: Introducing the OFG: Ornamental Forest Garden!
item.description: Yes, you can have it all, beauty and utility. Well, this is what I‚Äôm hoping to prove with the Ornamental Forest Garden.

item.title: My social media blog experiment
item.description: I have a love/hate relationship with social media. On the one hand, it has opened up completely new gardening and wildlife worlds, via groups such as #GdnBloggers.

item.title: Benefits of a forest garden
item.description: Forest gardening is a productive, low maintenance, wildlife friendly way to garden.

item.title: Top 10 bee friendly plants for the forest garden
item.description: The whole idea behind a forest garden is that it works with nature, to be as self-sustaining as possible.

item.title: A forest garden is a way to garden
item.description: I listened to the Margaret Roach podcast A Way to Garden, the episode entitled ‚ÄúGo ahead, we dare you: widen your plant palette‚Äù, with Andy Brand.

item.title: A Tale of Three Trees
item.description: Three years ago I planted 3 Alnus cordata (Italian Alder) along the top of the forest garden, all at the same time.

item.title: When you are dying, surround yourself with life
item.description: Dr Rachel Clarke @doctor_oxford, palliative care doctor and author, has written a beautiful piece in the New York Times called In Life‚Äôs Last Moments, Open a Window.

item.title: I‚Äôve had enough, it‚Äôs time to quit!
item.description: For the past 3 years I‚Äôve been leading a double life.

item.title: Nettle soup
item.description: Ingredients ¬Ω carrier bag stinging nettle tops 50g vegan margarine 1 large onion 1 litre vegetable stock 1 large potato, peeled & cut into cubes 1 large carrot, peeled & chopped Salt & pepper 2 tbsp Oatly creme fraiche Method Wash nettles, get rid of thick stalks, drain Melt vegan margarine in large saucepan, add onion, cook gently 5-7 minutes until softened Add stock, nettles, potato & carrot.

item.title: The Lure of the Stinging-less Nettle
item.description: The stinging nettle Urtica dioica is an excellent forest garden plant.

item.title: Vegan banana cake
item.description: We picked our first ever gooseberries last week. I washed them, popped them into a saucepan with a tiny bit of water, cooked them on a low heat for a few minutes until soft then added some sugar.

item.title: Definition
item.description: A forest garden mimics the edge of woodland and works with nature to grow produce sustainably for less work.

item.title: What is a Forest Garden?
item.description: With a forest garden, you can grow food sustainably for less work and more wildlife.

item.title: Vegan Chocolate Brownies
item.description: Ingredients 250g plain flour 350g demerara sugar 65g plain cocoa powder 1 tsp baking powder 1 tsp salt 250ml water 250ml vegetable oil 1 tsp vanilla extract Method Preheat the oven to 180¬∞C In a large bowl, stir together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking powder and salt.

item.title: Photographs from the Permaculture Tywi forest garden tour
item.description: Permaculture Tywi, a permaculture group from the Tywi Valley in Wales, came on a magnificent forest garden tour on Saturday 23rd June, as previously reported.

item.title: Permaculture Tywi forest garden tour
item.description: Permaculture Tywi from Llandeilo way (the Tywi Valley) came for a #ForestGarden tour last Saturday.

item.title: 7 Magical Things about Forest Gardens
item.description: I gave a talk recently to a local gardening club and I wanted to highlight the benefits of a forest garden in an accessible way (if you didn‚Äôt know, a forest garden is a productive way to garden using trees, shrubs and perennial plants).

item.title: The Green Tangle
item.description: As the saying goes, ‚ÄúYou can have a show garden or you can have a real garden‚Äù.

item.description: We‚Äôve taken the plunge and opened up the forest garden tours for individual members of the public to come along, rather than just taking group bookings.

item.description: Last year I experimented with a green mulch in the polytunnel.

item.title: Now using Netlify CMS!
item.description: With my web designer/developer hat on, I built the Forest Garden Wales website using an amazing static site generator called Hugo, with my own socially-aware starter theme called Indiego.

item.title: Heated propagator howto
item.description: http://www.bbc.co.uk/gardenersworld/video/toby_30minfix/heated_propagator.shtml Equipment needed: Screwdriver Drill 13mm wood drill bit Knife Pliers 6m long heating cable and compatible thermostatic control Screws to hold the sides together and attach to base RCD device to plug into wall socket if your fuse board doesn’t already contain one.

item.title: Forest garden tours now operating!
item.description: After the incredibly positive and encouraging feedback from The People‚Äôs Orchard and Permaculture Tywi, we‚Äôve decided to offer a half-day tour and talk of our forest garden in Ceredigion.

item.title: The Order of Things
item.description: Plan Windbreaks Propagation Canopy Mulch Ground cover Rabbit fence To be honest, this probably applies equally to all gardens!

item.title: The People‚Äôs Orchard visit Forest Garden Wales
item.description: After giving my first ever forest garden talk to The People‚Äôs Orchard back in March, Nia asked if they could have tour of Forest Garden Wales own forest garden.

item.title: The promise of planting a tree
item.description: There is nothing like the promise of planting a tree. On an overcast Thursday morning in mid-winter late April, Nia and Sophie from The People‚Äôs Orchard, with experienced orchardist Martin Hayes, led a small band of resilient volunteers in planting apple and plum trees by the car park at Poppit Sands in Pembrokeshire.

item.title: What blogging software do you use?
item.description: My alter ego is a web designer. This is a blessing and a curse, for I have spent too long building the new Forest Garden Wales website blog and not enought time gardening.

item.description: Clare Flynn, County Recorder, @wildaboutnature Reasons for Biological Recording Reliable biological data Conservation - knowing what is there Monitoring populations Planning land use Provides data for academic research 3 paths:

item.title: Plants that make mycorrhizal associations

item.description: Introduction Many gardeners add mycorrhizal fungi (like Chaos Fungorum or rootgrow‚Ñ¢) to roots when planting.

item.title: Don‚Äôt stake fruit trees
item.description: On a recent Planting & Pruning workshop held by The People‚Äôs Orchard, the orchardist Martin Hayes said a very interesting thing: don‚Äôt stake fruit trees unless they are dwarf ie if they are M26 or smaller.

item.title: About the name‚Ä¶
item.description: The name means ‚Äúa forest garden, in Wales‚Äù. It does not mean ‚ÄúThe Only Forest Garden in Wales‚Äù.

item.description: The idea of a blank canvas fills me with an odd sense of dread.

item.description: After a family outing to the local dump, I managed to pick up an almost completely knackered cupboard.

item.title: Misty valley whilst releasing mouse
item.description: Out on a walk to release the humanely caught mouse into the cold, cold woodland up the road, and the mist was all up and about the trees yet with blue sky above.

item.description: A roostock is the well developed root system on which you graft a known fruiting variety.

item.title: Predator strip!

item.title: Welcome to Forest Garden Wales website!
item.description: Welcome to our new website, built by Grow Digital. Like a garden, there is always plenty to do and we will be rolling out our new design soon.
